Award.AwardTitle: NetSE:Small: Human Behavior Inspired Cognitive Radio Network Design

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cognitive radios enabling dynamic spectrum access are envisioned to sense the environment and self-learn to maximize an individual or group utility function. This results in cheating, irrational behavior, inequality aversion, altruism, learning from past memory, etc. These traits are strikingly similar to human behavior and social interactions. Therefore, this project explores this parallelism going beyond traditional game theoretic analysis.

What are the implications if communication protocols in a cognitive radio network resemble human behavioral and psychological interactions? Will the network develop its own psychology with random perturbations, similar to human evolution?
These are the fundamental questions addressed in this project using tools from social science and behavioral games. Some of the main theoretical ideas will be implemented in SpiderRadio, a cognitive radio network prototype developed in the PIs? laboratory at Stevens.

Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit of this project is an inter-disciplinary effort that
overlaps human behavioral models, cognitive psychology, economic models, decision theory and dynamic spectrum access. Emerging social science concepts such as evolutionary and cognitive psychology, behavioral economics, drama theory, personal and social dilemmas are used to model various types of interactions among cognitive radio nodes in a network.

Broader Impact: The outcomes of this project will have a broader impact on wireless networking research and spectrum policy making communities. This project also gives a unique opportunity for students in engineering and psychology to collaborate. Finally, some of the ideas presented here will impact the next generation standards in cognitive radio networking.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cognitive radios sense the operating environment to self-learn while maximizing individual or group profits. This project investigated cognitive radio enabled dynamic spectrum access wireless networking. The exclusive and commons models for spectrum access were considered. While optimizing metrics such as maximum throughput or minimum latency it was observed that cognitive radio nodes can exhibit human like behaviors such as cheating, inequality aversion, altruism, learning from past experiences, and free-riding. Mathematical models for different wireless communications scenarios under which these behaviors are dominant were derived. Practical cognitive radio communication protocols were then designed based on the analyses, simulated using software and finally implemented in an integrated hardware-software prototype called SpiderRadio.

 

The intellectual merit of the project consists of the development of new mathematical models for cognitive radio networking encompassing behavioral game theory, micro-economic analysis and anthropological models. These models resulted in new joint resource optimization problems considering spectrum access opportunity, bandwidth, rate and latency. The solutions to these problems provided a number of new insights on the competitive/co-operative interaction between wireless service providers, self-learning medium access control protocols for spectrum access and the optimal parameters for sustaining video streaming over opportunistic wireless networks.

 

The outcomes of this project have had broader impact on spectrum policies and low cost rural wireless broadband. The PIs have participated in NITRD Wireless Spectrum Research and Development (WSRD) meetings to disseminate the research results. SpiderRadio was deployed and tested successfully in a low cost wireless broadband pilot trial in South Africa. The PIs have recently secured a NSF STTR Phase II grant to commercialize this technology. Secure, inter-operable public safety communications is a major theme of the commercialization effort.
